attributes.text:
This class is used to send HTTP requests to the server.

NOTE: Instances of this class must be disposed of after use

Note: This class will be deprecated in a future release. Instead, please use classes found in {@link qx.io.request}.
Target url to issue the request to.
Determines http method (GET, POST, PUT, etc.) to use. See “method” property for valid values and default value.
The mime type of the response. Default is text/plain.
Fired when the pending request has been aborted.
Fired on change of the property {@link #state}.
Fired once the request has finished successfully. The event object can be used to read the transferred data.
Fired when the Request object changes its state to ‘configured’
Fired when the Request object changes its state to ‘created’
Fired when the pending request fails.
Fired when the Request object changes its state to ‘receiving’
Fired when the Request object changes its state to ‘sending’
Fired when the pending request times out.
Sequence (id) number of a request, used to associate a response or error with its initiating request.
one of the values of the method property
Returns true if the given HTTP method allows a request body being transferred to the server. This is currently POST and PUT. Other methods require their data being encoded into the URL
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

Applies changes of the property value of the property method.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #method}.
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

Applies changes of the property value of the property prohibitCaching.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #prohibitCaching}.
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

Applies changes of the property value of the property responseType.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #responseType}.
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

Applies changes of the property value of the property state.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #state}.
Event indicating state change
Event handler called when the request enters the aborted state.
Event indicating state change
Event handler called when the request enters the completed state.
Event indicating state change
Event handler called when the request enters the failed state.
Event indicating state change
Event handler called when the request enters the queued state.
Event indicating state change
Event handler called when the request enters the receiving state.
Event indicating state change
Event handler called when the request enters the sending state.
Event indicating state change
Event handler called when the request enters the timeout state.

Abort sending this request.

The request is removed from the singleton class qx.io.remote.RequestQueue’s list of pending events. If the request haven’t been scheduled this method is a noop.

Returns the (computed) value of the property asynchronous.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #asynchronous}.
(Computed) value of asynchronous.

Returns the (computed) value of the property crossDomain.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #crossDomain}.
(Computed) value of crossDomain.

Returns the (computed) value of the property data.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #data}.
(Computed) value of data.

Returns the (computed) value of the property fileUpload.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #fileUpload}.
(Computed) value of fileUpload.
Identifier of the form field to get.
Get a form field in the POST request.
Value of form field or null if no value exists for the passed identifier.
Returns the object containing all form fields for the POST request.
The returned object has as its property names each of the ids of form fields which have been added, and as each property value, the value of the property corresponding to that id.

Returns the (computed) value of the property method.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #method}.
(Computed) value of method.
Identifier of the parameter to get.
If false then retrieve the parameter from the URL parameter list. If true then retrieve it from the list of parameters to be sent as request data.
Get a parameter in the request.
The requested parameter value
If false then retrieve the URL parameter list. If true then retrieve the data parameter list.
Returns the object containing all parameters for the request.
The returned object has as its property names each of the ids of parameters which have been added, and as each property value, the value of the property corresponding to that id.

Returns the (computed) value of the property parseJson.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #parseJson}.
(Computed) value of parseJson.

Returns the (computed) value of the property password.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #password}.
(Computed) value of password.

Returns the (computed) value of the property prohibitCaching.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #prohibitCaching}.
(Computed) value of prohibitCaching.
The id of the header value being requested
Retrieve the value of a header which was previously set
The value of the header with the specified id
Return the object containing all of the headers which have been added.
The returned object has as its property names each of the ids of headers which have been added, and as each property value, the value of the property corresponding to that id.

Returns the (computed) value of the property responseType.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #responseType}.

Obtain the sequence (id) number used for this request
The sequence number of this request

Identifier of the form field to remove.
Remove a form field from the POST request.
Identifier of the parameter to remove.
If false then remove the parameter of the URL parameter list. If true then remove it from the list of parameters to be sent as request data.
Remove a parameter from the request.
The id of the header to be removed
Remove a previously-added request header
Abort sending this request if it has not already been aborted.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #asynchronous}.

Schedule this request for transport to server.

The request is added to the singleton class qx.io.remote.RequestQueue’s list of pending requests.

The unmodified incoming value.
String identifier of the form field to add.
Value of form field

Add a form field to the POST request.

NOTE: Adding any programmatic form fields using this method will switch the Transport implementation to IframeTransport.

NOTE: Use of these programmatic form fields disallow use of synchronous requests and cross-domain requests. Be sure that you do not need those features when setting these programmatic form fields.
New value for property method.

Sets the user value of the property method.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #method}.
The unmodified incoming value.
String identifier of the parameter to add.
Value of parameter. May be a string (for one parameter) or an array of strings (for setting multiple parameter values with the same parameter name).

If false, add the parameter to the URL. If true then instead the parameters added by calls to this method will be combined into a string added as the request data, as if the entire set of parameters had been pre-build and passed to setData(). Note: Parameters requested to be sent as data will be silently dropped if data is manually added via a call to setData(). Note: Some transports, e.g. Script, do not support passing parameters as data.
Add a parameter to the request.
New value for property parseJson.

Sets the user value of the property parseJson.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #parseJson}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property password.

Sets the user value of the property password.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #password}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property prohibitCaching.

Sets the user value of the property prohibitCaching.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #prohibitCaching}.
The unmodified incoming value.
The identifier to use for this added header
The value to use for this added header

Add a request header to the request.

Example: request.setRequestHeader(“Content-Type”, “text/html”)

Please note: Some browsers, such as Safari 3 and 4, will capitalize header field names. This is in accordance with RFC 26161, which states that HTTP 1.1 header names are case-insensitive, so your server backend should be case-agnostic when dealing with request headers.

[1]RFC 2616: HTTP Message Headers

Set the request to asynchronous.

Indicate that the request is cross domain.

A request is cross domain if the request’s URL points to a host other than the local host. This switches the concrete implementation that is used for sending the request from qx.io.remote.transport.XmlHttp to qx.io.remote.transport.Script, because only the latter can handle cross domain requests.
Set the data to be sent via this request

Indicate that the request will be used for a file upload.

The request will be used for a file upload. This switches the concrete implementation that is used for sending the request from qx.io.remote.transport.XmlHttp to qx.io.remote.IFrameTransport, because only the latter can handle file uploads.
Determines what type of request to issue (GET, POST, PUT, HEAD, DELETE).

If true and the responseType property is set to “application/json”, getContent() will return a Javascript map containing the JSON contents, i. e. the result qx.lang.Json.parse(). If false, the raw string data will be returned and the parsing must be done manually. This is useful for special JSON dialects / extensions which are not supported by qx.lang.Json.

Note that this is currently only respected by qx.io.remote.transport.XmlHttp, i. e. if the transport used is the one using XMLHttpRequests. The other transports do not support JSON parsing, so this property has no effect.
Password to use for HTTP authentication. Set to NULL if HTTP authentication is not used.

Prohibit request from being cached.

Setting the value to true adds a parameter “nocache” to the request URL with a value of the current time, as well as adding request headers Pragma:no-cache and Cache-Control:no-cache.

Setting the value to false removes the parameter and request headers.

As a special case, this property may be set to the string value “no-url-params-on-post” which will prevent the nocache parameter from being added to the URL if the POST method is used but will still add the Pragma and Cache-Control headers. This is useful if your backend does nasty things like mixing parameters specified in the URL into form fields in the POST request. (One example of this nasty behavior is known as “mixed mode” in Oracle, as described here: http://docs.oracle.com/cd/B32110_01/web.1013/b28963/concept.htm#i1005684)

Response type of request.

The response type is a MIME type, default is text/plain. Other supported MIME types are text/javascript, text/html, application/json, application/xml.
The state that the request is in, while being processed.

Number of milliseconds before the request is being timed out.

If this property is null, the timeout for the request comes is the qx.io.remote.RequestQueue’s property defaultTimeout.

The transport instance used for the request.

This is necessary to be able to abort an asynchronous request.
Target url to issue the request to.
Use Basic HTTP Authentication.
Username to use for HTTP authentication. Set to NULL if HTTP authentication is not used.
